text: EMN-KCMD Statistical annex of the 2020 EU Annual Report on Migration and Asylum Belmonte, Martina Sermi, Francesco 2021

This publication is a Technical report by the Joint Research Centre (JRC), the European Commission’s science and knowledge service. It aims to provide evidence-based scientific support to the European policymaking process. The scientific output expressed does not imply a policy position of the European Commission. Neither the European Commission nor any person acting on behalf of the Commission is responsible for the use that might be made of this publication. For information on the methodology and quality underlying the data used in this publication for which the source is neither Eurostat nor other Commission services, users should contact the referenced source. The designations employed and the presentation of material on the maps do not imply the expression of any opinion whatsoever on the part of the European Union concerning the legal status of any country, territory, city or area or of its authorities, or concerning the delimitation of its frontiers or boundaries. Contact information Name: Martina Belmonte Address: Via Enrico Fermi 2749 I-21027 Ispra/Italy Email: martina.belmonte@ec.europa.eu Tel.: +39 0332 789821 EU Science Hub https://ec.europa.eu/jrc JRC126380 PDF ISBN 978-92-76-41165-9 doi:10.2760/53711 Print ISBN 978-92-76-41166-6 doi:10.2760/368070 Luxembourg: Publications Office of the European Union, 2021 © European Union, 2021 The reuse policy of the European Commission is implemented by the Commission Decision 2011/833/EU of 12 December 2011 on the reuse of Commission documents (OJ L 330, 14.12.2011, p. 39). Except otherwise noted, the reuse of this document is authorised under the Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International (CC BY 4.0) licence (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/). This means that reuse is allowed provided appropriate credit is given and any changes are indicated. For any use or reproduction of photos or other material that is not owned by the EU, permission must be sought directly from the copyright holders. All content © European Union, 2021 How to cite this report: Belmonte, M., Sermi, F. EMN-KCMD Statistical annex of the 2020 EU Annual Report on Migration and Asylum, Publications Office of the European Union, Luxembourg, 2021, ISBN 978-92-76-41165-9, doi:10.2760/53711, JRC126380 XX - N A - XXXXX - E N - N

Content This statistical annex complements the 2020 Annual Report on Migration and Asylum EU , produced by the European Migration Network (EMN) and available at the following link: https://ec.europa.eu/home- affairs/networks/european-migration-network-emn/emn-publications/annual-reports-migration-and- asylum_en?f%5B0%5D=country_country%3Ahttp%3A//publications.europa.eu/resource/authority/country/EUR. It mirrors the statistical annexes of the EMN Country Factsheets, available at the following link: https://ec.europa.eu/home-affairs/networks/european-migration-network-emn/emn-publications/country- factsheets_en In this document, you will find the ‘How to read the statistical annex’ , explaining the data shown chart by chart, along with the data source, and the statistical annex of the EU.

First residence permits annually issued: total number and % of population The bars show the number of first residence permits issued every year for the last four years. The percentages on the top of each bar show the share of permits over the population of EU and Norway. Please note that due to a later publication date by the source, data covers an earlier four-year period. Link to data source : http://appsso.eurostat.ec.europa.eu/nui/show.do?dataset=migr_resfir st&lang=en https://appsso.eurostat.ec.europa.eu/nui/show.do?dataset=migr_pop 1ctz&lang=en Top 3 nationalities of number of first residence permits annually issued: number of permits and % of total annual permits The bars show the number of first residence permits issued annually to the top three nationalities, in absolute number and as a percentage of the total number of residence permits issued (to known nationalities) by the country in each year. Please note that due to a later publication date by the source, data covers an earlier four-year period. If more than one nationality occupies the last position, only one is displayed (following an inverse alphabetical order). Link to data source https://appsso.eurostat.ec.europa.eu/nui/show.do?dataset=migr_resfi rst&lang=en First residence permits annually issued by reason The chart shows the types of first residence permits issued, by reason: Remunerated activities (‘Work’), Family, Education and Other. Link to data source http://appsso.eurostat.ec.europa.eu/ nui/show.do?dataset=migr_resfirst&l ang=en EMN EU27 & Norway Factsheet How to read the statistical annex GENERAL NOTES These four pages describe each individual chart in the statistical annex. It also provides links to the data sources. The extraction date is 9 September 2021 for all sources. For any question, please contact EMN or KCMD. EMN Country Factsheets are available here. For comparability purposes, EU values are calculated on the basis of the EU-27 Member States, following Eurostat’s aggregate ‘EU27 countries (from 2020)’. Data always refer to EU27+Norway, unless otherwise specified. LEGAL MIGRATION AND MOBILITY COLOR LEGEND This colour/symbol code is used throughout the annex. Third-Country Nationals as % of total population The bars show the number of people residing in EU Member States and Norway with the citizenship of a non-EU Member States. This is shown as an absolute number (right-hand side) and as a share of the total population of the EU and Norway (within the bars). Data covers the last four years. Link to data source : https://appsso.eurostat.ec.europa.eu/nui/show.do?dataset=migr_pop1ctz&lang=en First residence permits annually issued for work reasons The chart shows the sub-types of first residence permits issued for ‘Work’. The categories are: highly skilled workers, researchers, EU Blue Cards, seasonal workers and other. Only the ones for which permits are issued are shown. Link to data source https://appsso.eurostat.ec.europa.eu/nui/sho w.do?dataset=migr_resocc&lang=en First residence permits annually issued for ‘other’ reasons The chart shows the sub-types of first residence permits issued for ‘Other reasons’. The categories are: refugee and subsidiary protection, humanitarian reasons, residence only, unaccompanied minors, victims of trafficking in human beings, and other. Only the ones for which permits are issued are shown. Link to data source https://appsso.eurostat.ec.europa.eu/nui/show.do?d ataset=migr_resoth&lang=en

Top 3 nationalities of annual number of first instance decisions: number of decisions (% of total decisions in the country) and % of positive outcome The chart shows the three nationalities with the highest number of asylum decisions, each year for the last four years (rounded data). The number of decisions taken for each nationality are reported on the right of the bar. This is shown as an absolute number and as a share of the total number of decisions taken in the country in the year. The outcome of the decision (positive or negative) is indicated by the colours and by the percentages in the relevant part of the bars (positive decisions only). If more than one nationality occupies the third position, only one is displayed (following an inverse alphabetical order). Link to data source: http://appsso.eurostat.ec.europa.eu/nui/show.do?dataset=migr_asy dcfsta&lang=en INTERNATIONAL PROTECTION INCLUDING ASYLUM Top 3 nationalities of annual number of first-time asylum applications: number of applications and % of total annual applications The chart shows the top three nationalities of people who have lodged applications for asylum (rounded data). The top three nationalities are sorted top-down by decreasing number of first-time asylum applications. The number of annual applications per nationality and the share of these over the total annual applications in the EU and Norway are shown. If more than one nationality occupies the third position, only one is displayed (following an inverse alphabetical order). Link to data source: http://appsso.eurostat.ec.europa.eu/nui/show.do?dataset=migr_a syappctza&lang=en Total and first time asylum applications; first time asylum applications as a % of the population The grey and blue bars show respectively the annual number of total and first-time asylum applications for the last four years (rounded data). The percentages below the bars show the share of first time asylum applications over the population in the EU27 and Norway. Link to data source: https://appsso.eurostat.ec.europa.eu/nui/show.do?dataset=migr_as yappctza&lang=en https://appsso.eurostat.ec.europa.eu/nui/show.do?dataset=migr_po p1ctz&lang=en Number of first instance asylum decisions by outcome (% of total decisions) The chart shows the number (and share) of first-instance decisions on asylum applications by outcome (rounded data). It shows this for the last four years. It also shows the total number of decisions taken (right side of the bar). The possible outcomes are: ‘Geneva Convention status’ (blue); ‘Subsidiary protection’ (light blue); ‘Humanitarian protection’ (cyan); and ‘Rejected application’ (grey). Link to data source: http://appsso.eurostat.ec.europa.eu/nui/show.do?dataset=migr_asydcfsta&lang=en Third-Country Nationals resettled: absolute number and as % total resettled in EU The chart shows the number of Third-Country Nationals resettled to the country each year over the last four years (rounded data). Link to data source https://appsso.eurostat.ec.europa.eu/nui/show.do?dataset=migr_as yresa&lang=en

Stateless, Recognised Non-Citizens (RNC) and Unknown Citizens The chart shows the number of people usually residing in the country and i) who are not considered as nationals by any State under the operation of its law (‘Stateless’ in blue); ii) who are not citizens of the reporting country nor of any other country, but who have established links to that country which include some but not all rights and obligations of full citizenship (‘Recognised Non- Citizens’ in light- blue); or iii) whose citizenship is unknown (‘Unknown citizens’ in dark blue); in a given year over the last four years. Link to data source : https://appsso.eurostat.ec.europa.eu/nui/show.do?dataset=migr_pop1ctz&la ng=en Third-Country Nationals who have acquired citizenship in absolute number The chart shows the number of TCNs who have acquired the citizenship of the country in absolute. Link to data source : http://appsso.eurostat.ec.europa.eu/nui/show.do?dataset= migr_acq&lang=en The chart is divided into three subtopics, each described by two indicators. The value of the indicator [as %] is given for ‘Nationals’ (i.e. citizens of the Member State) and Third-Country Nationals – ‘TCNs’, i.e. citizens of non-EU27 countries nor reporting country. Data refer to the EU27 only. Social inclusion Persons at risk of poverty or social exclusion (18+) shows the percentage of adults who are either at risk of poverty, face serious material deprivation or live in a household defined as having a ‘very low work intensity’. Link to data source: http://appsso.eurostat.ec.europa.eu/nui/show.do?dataset=ilc_peps05&lang=en Overcrowding rate (18+) shows the percentage of adults who live in a household defined as ‘overcrowded’. Link to data source: http://appsso.eurostat.ec.europa.eu/nui/show.do?dataset=ilc_lvho15&lang=en Education Early school leavers (18-24) shows the proportion of people aged between 18 and 24 which has completed no more than lower secondary education and is not involved in further education or training. Link to data source : http://appsso.eurostat.ec.europa.eu/nui/show.do?dataset=edat_lfse_01&lang=en Neither Employed nor in Education or Training (18-24) shows the proportion of people aged between 18 and 24 who are Neither Employed nor in Education or Training in the four weeks preceding the survey. Link to data source : http://appsso.eurostat.ec.europa.eu/nui/show.do?dataset=edat_lfse_23&lang=en Labour market Employment rate (15-64) shows the percentage of the total working-age population which is employed. Link to data source : http://appsso.eurostat.ec.europa.eu/nui/show.do?dataset=lfsa_ergan&lang=en Unemployment rate (15-64) indicates the percentage of unemployed people in the labour force. It is calculated as the ratio between the unemployed population over the sum of employed and unemployed population within the same group. Link to data source : http://appsso.eurostat.ec.europa.eu/nui/show.do?dataset=lfsa_urgan&lang=en Unaccompanied minors applying for asylum The bars show the number of unaccompanied minors applying for asylum for the past four years in the country as an absolute number (rounded). Please note that not all unaccompanied minors apply for asylum. Link to data source: https://appsso.eurostat.ec.europa.eu/nui/show.do?dataset=migr_asyunaa&lang=en; https://appsso.eurostat.ec.europa.eu/nui/show.do?dataset=migr_asyappctza&lang=en Unaccompanied minors as % of first asylum applications The bars show the share of asylum applications lodged by unaccompanied minors over the total number of asylum applications during the same year (based on rounded data). Data source on the left. UNACCOMPANIED MINORS CITIZENSHIP AND STATELESSNESS Top 3 nationalities by number of citizenship acquisition in the last available year: absolute number and % of total acquisitions in the country The chart shows the top three nationalities groups of people who acquired citizenship in the last available year. It shows this as an absolute number and as a share of the total number of citizenship acquisitions. If more than one nationality occupies the fifth position, only one is displayed (following an inverse alphabetical order). Link to data source : http://appsso.eurostat.ec.europa.eu/nui/show.do?dataset=migr_acq&lang=en INTEGRATION

Number of residence permits issued to victims of Trafficking in Human Beings The chart shows the number of residence permits issued to victims of Trafficking in Human Beings for the last four years. Please note that due to a later publication date by the source, data covers an earlier four-year period. Link to data source: https://appsso.eurostat.ec.europa.eu/nui/show.do?da taset=migr_resoth&lang=en Short stay Visas issued The chart shows the number of short stay visas annually issued in the EU Member States’ and Norway’s consulates around the world for the last four years. For Schengen countries, short stay visas include uniform visas (entitling the holder to stay in the territories of all Member States for a period of maximum 90 days within 180 days and that may be issued for a single entry or multiple entries (MEVs)), visas with limited territorial validity (LTVs), and airport transit visa (ATVs). Please note that the Member State whose consulate receives the visa application may be different from the Member State of main destination. Bulgaria, Croatia, Cyprus and Romania do not yet issue uniform Schengen visas. For these Member States, the figures refer to national short-stay visas (including MEVs). Link to data source : https://ec.europa.eu/home-affairs/what-we- do/policies/borders-and-visas/visa-policy_en BORDERS, SCHENGEN AND VISAS Uniform Visas issued in top 3 consulate countries (% of total applications) The chart shows the number of visas issued in the three consulate countries with the largest total number of issued visas. It shows this as an absolute number and as a share of total visas issued. Please note that the consulate country might not be the same as the country of citizenship of the visa applicant, as this information is not available at the EU level. If more than one nationality occupies the third position, only one is displayed (following an inverse alphabetical order). Link to data source : https://ec.europa.eu/home- affairs/what- we-do/policies/borders-and-visas/visa- policy_en IRREGULAR MIGRATION The chart gives an overview of the trend for the last four years regarding the following parameters commonly related to ‘irregular migration’. All data are rounded:  Refused entry at the external borders – Third-Country Nationals formally refused permission to enter the territory of a country during controls at its external borders (including airports, harbours and borderlines). Link to data source : https://appsso.eurostat.ec.europa.eu/nui/show.do?dataset=migr_eirfs&lang=en  Founded to be illegally present – Third-Country Nationals who are detected by a country's authorities and have been determined to be illegally present (people who have been found to have entered irregularly as well as to those who may have entered legally but remained on an illegal basis, i.e. overstaying their permission to remain) under national laws relating to immigration. Link to data source : http://appsso.eurostat.ec.europa.eu/nui/show.do?dataset=migr_eipre&lang=en  Ordered to leave the country (OTL) – Third-Country Nationals who are subject to an administrative or judicial decision or act stating that their stay is irregular and imposing an obligation to leave the territory of the country. At the bottom, the chart on the left shows the top 3 nationalities ordered to leave – in absolute number and as a share of all nationalities ordered to leave in the country. Link to data source : http://appsso.eurostat.ec.europa.eu/nui/show.do?dataset=migr_eiord&lang=en  Returned to a third country following an OTL – Third-Country Nationals who have left the territory of the Member State, following an administrative or judicial decision or act stating that their stay is irregular and imposing an obligation to leave the territory. At the bottom, the chart on the right shows the top 3 nationalities returned to a third country after an order to leave was issued – in absolute number and as a share of all nationalities ordered to leave in the country. Link to data source : https://appsso.eurostat.ec.europa.eu/nui/show.do?dataset=migr_eirtn&lang=en RETURN AND READMISSION TRAFFICKING OF HUMAN BEING Number of Third-Country Nationals who left the territory by type of return The chart shows the number (rounded) of Third-Country Nationals who left the territory following an order to leave (OTL) by type of return (in percentage): enforced (blue), voluntary (cyan) and other types (dark blue), which refer to the situation in which it can be reasonably presumed that the Third-Country National returned based on some assumptions. The total number of total annual returns is on the right. Link to data source: https://appsso.eurostat.ec.europa.eu/nui/show.do?dataset=migr_eirt_vol&lang =en

European Union & Norway - 2020 Publication date: September 2021 GENERAL NOTES This four-page statistical annex presents relevant migration-related data organised in up to nine thematic sections - depending on data availability. The dashboard-like layout of the annex allows comparability across countries as well as simultaneous visualisation of different indicators. Data are provided for the latest available year or the latest available four-year period. For some indicators, data are rounded in the source. The sum of percentages or of individual values might not add up to 100 or to the total value. This is due to rounding and confidence intervals in the original data. A How to Read guide, describing each chart and reporting the sources, is available on the EMN website. COLOUR LEGEND Whenever not specified, the following colour legend is adopted. Colours for multiple nationalities are randomly chosen. data relative to the EU (2020 composition) + Norway LEGAL MIGRATION AND MOBILITY Third-Country Nationals (TCNs) as % of total population SOURCE: Eurostat (migr_pop1ctz) Number of TCNs 2017 2018 2019 2020 5.1% 4.8% 4.7% 4.5% 23 108 032 21 862 896 21 121 255 20 161 168 Top 3 nationalities of number of first residence permits annually issued: number of permits and % of total annual permits SOURCE: Eurostat (migr_resfirst) 2016 2017 2018 2019 Morocco 98 388 (3.9% ) Syria 353 522 (14.0% ) Ukraine 582 157 (23.0% ) Morocco 107 084 (3.9% ) Syria 224 030 (8.2% ) Ukraine 662 842 (24.3% ) Morocco 125 928 (4.5% ) Syria 173 135 (6.1% ) Ukraine 635 331 (22.6% ) Morocco 133 100 (4.5% ) India 134 321 (4.5% ) Ukraine 758 069 (25.4% ) First residence permits annually issued: total number and % of total population SOURCE: Eurostat (migr_resfirst) 2016 2017 2018 2019 0.56% 0.61% 0.62% 0.66% 2 5 3 2 8 6 9 2 7 3 1 7 3 9 2 8 1 5 7 4 9 2 9 8 0 8 4 4 First residence permits annually issued by reason in 2019 SOURCE: Eurostat (migr_resfirst) 14% 28% 40% 18% Reason Family Education Work Other First residence permits annually issued for work reasons in 2019 SOURCE: Eurostat (migr_resocc) 2% 1% 4% 42% 51% Working reason EU Blue Card Researcher Highly skilled Seasonal Other First residence permits annually issued for 'other reasons' in 2019 SOURCE: Eurostat (migr_resoth) 32% 35% 15% 17% Other reason Refugee/Sub.Prot. Residence only Humanitarian Not specified

European Union & Norway - 2020 Publication date: September 2021 INTERNATIONAL PROTECTION INCLUDING ASYLUM Total/first-time asylum applications; first-time asylum applications as % of total population SOURCE: Eurostat (migr_asyappctza, migr_pop1ctz) 2017 2018 2019 2020 473 605 681 265 628 505 701 400 6 2 3 8 5 0 5 6 6 8 8 5 6 3 3 7 7 5 4 1 8 9 6 0 0.09% 0.14% 0.13% 0.14% Top 3 nationalities of annual number of first-time asylum applications: number of applications and % of total first-time annual applications SOURCE: Eurostat (migr_asyappctza) 2017 2018 2019 2020 Afghanistan 41 975 (7%) Iraq 44 435 (7%) Syria 102 590 (16%) Iraq 36 795 (6%) Afghanistan 40 715 (7%) Syria 80 930 (14%) Venezuela 44 790 (7%) Afghanistan 54 395 (9%) Syria 75 450 (12%) Venezuela 30 340 (7%) Afghanistan 44 340 (11%) Syria 64 205 (15%) Number of first-instance asylum decisions by outcome (% of total decisions) SOURCE: Eurostat (migr_asydcfsta) 2017 2018 2019 2020 522 765 (100%) 543 570 (100%) 555 250 (100%) 940 785 (100%) 60 660 (11%) 107 140 (20%) 110 625 (20%) 115 770 (21%) 214 920 (23%) 50 320 (10%) 52 030 (10%) 155 245 (17%) 55 500 (11%) 45 165 (8%) 32 355 (6%) 63 595 (7%) 309 805 (59%) 335 750 (62%) 346 465 (62%) 507 025 (54%) Geneva Convention Subsidiary protection Humanitarian protection Rejected application Top 3 nationalities of annual number of first-instance decisions: number of decisions (% of total decisions in the country) and % of positive outcome SOURCE: Eurostat (migr_asydcfsta) 2017 2018 2019 2020 Iraq 96 685 (10%) Syria 145 850 (16%) Afghanistan 176 065 (19%) Iraq 39 395 (7%) Afghanistan 55 940 (10%) Syria 71 595 (13%) Afghanistan 34 170 (6%) Venezuela 38 700 (7%) Syria 69 450 (13%) Colombia 42 575 (8%) Venezuela 49 290 (9%) Syria 74 820 (14%) 57% 94% 47% 44% 46% 88% 54% 96% 85% 3% 95% 85% Positive Negative Third-Country Nationals resettled: absolute number SOURCE: Eurostat (migr_asyresa) 2017 2018 2019 2020 20 755 21 505 24 090 10 250 first-time total

European Union & Norway - 2020 Publication date: September 2021 UNACCOMPANIED MINORS Unaccompanied minors applying for asylum SOURCE: Eurostat (migr_asyunaa) 2017 2018 2019 2020 29 380 16 935 14 245 13 635 Unaccompanied minors as % of first asylum applications SOURCE: Eurostat (migr_asyunaa) 2017 2018 2019 2020 4.7% 3.0% 2.2% 3.3% INTEGRATION Integration indicators for nationals of the country (blue) and Third-Country Nationals (TCNs - light blue) in the country (when available). Data are relative to the last available year and refer to EU27 only. SOURCE: Eurostat (ilc_peps05, ilc_lvho15, edat_lfse_01, edat_lfse_23, lfsa_ergan, lfsa_urgan) Social inclusion (2019) Education (2020) Labour market (2020) At risk of poverty or social exclusion (18+) Overcrowding rate (18+) Early school leavers (18-24) Neither Employed nor in Education or Training (18-24) Employment rate (15-64) Unemployment rate (15-64) Nationals TCNs 19.6% 45.3% Nationals TCNs 14.3% 34.8% Nationals TCNs 28.2% 8.6% Nationals TCNs 13.5% 27.2% Nationals TCNs 68.3% 55.1% Nationals TCNs 17.0% 6.6% CITIZENSHIP AND STATELESSNESS Third-Country Nationals who have acquired citizenship in absolute number SOURCE: Eurostat (migr_acq) 2016 2017 2018 2019 610 149 574 773 614 341 748 806 Stateless, unknown citizens and recognised non-citizens (RNC) SOURCE: Eurostat (migr_pop1ctza) 2017 2018 2019 2020 483 216 466 289 443 452 428 847 64 007 70 857 76 178 74 587 269 267 279 161 289 867 300 800 95 573 93 434 100 244 107 829 Unknown RNC Stateless Top 3 nationalities by number of citizenship acquisition in 2019: absolute number and % of total acquisitions by Third-Country Nationals SOURCE: Eurostat (migr_acq) 2019 United Kingdom 29 865 (4.9%) Albania 41 708 (6.8%) Morocco 66 835 (11.0%)

GETTING IN TOUCH WITH THE EU In person All over the European Union there are hundreds of Europe Direct information centres. You can find the address of the centre nearest you at: https://europa.eu/european-union/contact_en On the phone or by email Europe Direct is a service that answers your questions about the European Union. You can contact this service: - by freephone: 00 800 6 7 8 9 10 11 (certain operators may charge for these calls), - at the following standard number: +32 22999696, or - by electronic mail via: https://europa.eu/european-union/contact_en FINDING INFORMATION ABOUT THE EU Online Information about the European Union in all the official languages of the EU is available on the Europa website at: https://europa.eu/european-union/index_en EU publications You can download or order free and priced EU publications from EU Bookshop at: https://publications.europa.eu/en/publications. Multiple copies of free publications may be obtained by contacting Europe Direct or your local information centre (see https://europa.eu/european- union/contact_en).
